title: New typeface Aeronaut: Blackletter meets Steampunk
content:
[
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701003633im_/http:/typophile.com/files/32472_5021.jpg)
](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701003633/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/facetype/aeronaut/)

This new typeface [Aeronaut](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701003633/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/facetype/aeronaut/) is like [Blackletter](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701003633/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Blackletter) meets Steampunk. Can't readily think of a use for this, but that won't stop me from admiring it.
author: Joe Pemberton

comments.content:
It looks great! Reminds me of that mad Ludwig's Castle. European Chocolates?

Cheers!

:) dressy and interesting in the the small bits, but not whorish either

looks like the details start getting lost a smaller pt sizes, but even then its still legible
I'm thinking it must be from a historic source. There are at least 2 other blackletters that are like it on MyFonts with some very minor details that vary. None of them mention a source.

I recently used Aeronaut on a small project that called for a futuristic Victorian feel (think Tim Burton style without the darkness). Used it alongside Knockout. Very nice!

I was compelled to adjust the _f_ and _y_ after converting a title to outlines. (See "fly" in the preview above).

Enjoy!

Thomas Pynchon's massive steam-punk novel Against the Day has the "Chums of Chance" floating all over the world in a huge lighter-than-air craft. Perhaps it's a reference? ;-)

[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Against\_the\_Day](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701003633/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Against_the_Day "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Against\_the\_Day")

Happy 2010, all you Typonauts!

[http://slowprint.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701003633/http:/slowprint.com/ "http://slowprint.com/") Letterpress for Typographers!  
 [http://alphabets.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701003633/http:/alphabets.com/ "http://alphabets.com/")
Very nice! Made me instantly think of Rheingold too.

Some little history on the style:  
 [http://typophile.com/node/15909](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701003633/http:/typophile.com/node/15909 "http://typophile.com/node/15909")
For some reason I thought of Terry Gilliam... Baron Von Munchausen. I like it.

That was an amazing movie!

hhp

Aye, Chris, great movie and Terry Gilliam rules. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry\_Gilliam](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701003633/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Gilliam "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry\_Gilliam")
